page.title: 08LITTLE EAST STANDEN BARN
page.content: The Barn at Little East Standen Farm is older than the farm house itself. On the walls are carvings of dates from 1200 to 1926. There are also tally marks on the bricks which the workers would have used. Wall markings reveal the enlargements of the barn where larger machinery needed extra storage room. The pine beams are thought to have come from a ship. In the barn is a doorway that leads into the oldest part which is the mill. It hasn't been extended so it is lower than the barn itself. Attached to the barn is a round building which from Saxon times was used by a donkey which turned the millstone. The roof of the mill is slate though earlier was thatch. The mill is the only one of its kind on the Island and dates to medieval times
